Featured Pinoy Dishes

Filipino Style
Chicken Adobo

See complete recipe

chef_hat

Chicken Adobo

INGREDIENTS

1 kg chicken (cut into serving pieces)

1/2 cup soy sauce

1/4 cup vinegar

1 cup water

6 cloves garlic (minced)

1 onion (sliced)

2 bay leaves

1 tsp black peppercorns (or ground black pepper)

1 tbsp brown sugar (optional)

2 tbsp cooking oil

1/2 tsp salt (adjust to taste)

HOW TO COOK?

1. Marinate the Chicken
In a bowl, combine the chicken, soy sauce, minced garlic, and black pepper. Mix well and let it marinate for at least 30 minutes (or overnight for better flavor).

2. SautÃ© the Aromatics
Heat the cooking oil in a pan over medium heat. SautÃ© the onion until soft, then add the marinated chicken (reserve the marinade). Sear the chicken until slightly browned on both sides.

3. Simmer the Adobo
Pour in the reserved marinade, water, and bay leaves. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low. Cover and let it simmer for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally.

4. Add Vinegar & Adjust Seasoning
Pour in the vinegar (do not stir yet) and let it cook uncovered for about 5 minutes to remove the strong acidic taste. Stir and add brown sugar (if using) and salt to taste.

5. Reduce the Sauce & Serve
Let it simmer uncovered for another 10 minutes until the sauce thickens to your desired consistency. Serve hot with steamed rice and enjoy!

Sinigang
Na Baboy

See complete recipe

chef_hat

Sinigang na Baboy

INGREDIENTS

1 kg pork belly or ribs (cut into chunks)

1 medium onion (quartered)

2 medium tomatoes (quartered)

1 pack sinigang mix (or fresh tamarind, if preferred)

8 cups water

1 cup daikon radish (sliced)

1 cup sitaw (string beans, cut into 2-inch pieces)

2 pcs eggplant (sliced)

1 cup kangkong (water spinach) leaves

2 pcs long green chili (optional, for heat)

Salt or fish sauce (patis), to taste

HOW TO COOK?

1. Boil the Pork
In a large pot, combine the pork, onion, and tomatoes with the water. Bring to a boil and then simmer for about 45 minutes to 1 hour, or until pork is tender. Skim off any scum that rises to the surface.

2. Add the Vegetables
Once pork is tender, add the radish and simmer for 5 minutes. Then add the eggplant and sitaw, and simmer for another 5-7 minutes until vegetables are cooked but not mushy.

3. Make it Sour
Add the sinigang mix or fresh tamarind extract. Stir well and adjust the sourness to your preference. Add the green chili if you like a bit of a kick.

4. Season & Final Touch
Season with salt or fish sauce to taste. Finally, add the kangkong leaves and simmer for 1-2 minutes until wilted.

5. Serve Hot
Serve steaming hot with rice and maybe a side of patis with sili. Enjoy your comforting bowl of sinigang!

Laing

See complete recipe

chef_hat

Laing

INGREDIENTS

2 cups dried gabi (taro) leaves

400 ml coconut milk

250 ml coconut cream (kakang gata)

1/2 cup dried shrimp or pork belly (optional)

6 cloves garlic (minced)

1 onion (chopped)

1 thumb-sized ginger (sliced into strips)

3-5 pcs red chili or siling labuyo (adjust to heat preference)

2 tbsp fish sauce (or to taste)

Salt to taste

HOW TO COOK?

1. SautÃ© Aromatics
In a pan, sautÃ© garlic, onion, and ginger until fragrant. Add your shrimp or pork if using and cook until slightly browned.

2. Add Coconut Milk
Pour in the coconut milk and bring to a gentle simmer. Add the fish sauce and chilies.

3. Add Gabi Leaves
Carefully add the dried taro leaves without stirring (to avoid itchiness). Let it cook on low heat, covered, for about 30â€“40 minutes or until leaves are soft and fully absorbed the liquid.

4. Add Coconut Cream
Pour in the coconut cream and simmer for another 10 minutes uncovered, until thick and creamy. Season with more salt if needed.

5. Serve with Rice
Serve hot with a mound of steamed rice. Optional: Add more chili oil if you like it spicy!

Kare-Kare

See complete recipe

chef_hat

Kare-Kare

INGREDIENTS

1 kg oxtail or beef tripe (or both)

1 banana heart (sliced)

1 bunch sitaw (string beans)

2 pcs eggplant (sliced)

1 bundle pechay or bok choy

1/2 cup peanut butter

1/4 cup ground toasted rice

1 tbsp annatto seeds (soaked in warm water) or annatto powder

6 cups water

1 onion (chopped)

4 cloves garlic (minced)

Salt and pepper to taste

Bagoong (fermented shrimp paste) for serving

HOW TO COOK?

1. Boil the Meat
Boil the oxtail or tripe until tender (this may take 1.5 to 2 hours). Set aside the broth.

2. SautÃ© the Base
In a pan, sautÃ© garlic and onion in a bit of oil. Add the tender meat and sautÃ© briefly.

3. Add Sauce Components
Pour in the broth and add peanut butter, ground rice, and annatto water. Stir until well blended and thickened.

4. Add the Veggies
Add banana heart, eggplant, and sitaw. Simmer until vegetables are tender. Lastly, add the pechay.

5. Serve with Bagoong
Serve hot with steamed rice and a side of bagoong. This is where the magic happens!

Tocilog

See complete recipe

chef_hat

Tocilog

INGREDIENTS

500g tocino (store-bought or homemade)

3 cloves garlic (minced)

Cooked garlic fried rice (sinangag)

3 eggs

Cooking oil

HOW TO COOK?

1. Cook the Tocino
In a pan, add the tocino with a bit of water. Cover and simmer until water evaporates, then let it caramelize in its own fat. Add oil if needed.

2. Make the Garlic Rice
In another pan, sautÃ© garlic until golden brown. Add cold rice and stir-fry until heated through. Season with salt to taste.

3. Fry the Eggs
Fry the eggs sunny-side up or however you like them.

4. Plate & Serve
Serve the tocino, garlic rice, and egg together. Optionally serve with sliced tomatoes or pickled papaya (atchara).

Pork Sisig

See complete recipe

chef_hat

PORK SISIG

INGREDIENTS

500g pork belly or pork face (maskara)

1 onion (finely chopped)

2 cloves garlic (minced)

2 pcs calamansi or 1 tbsp lemon juice

1-2 tbsp mayonnaise

1 tbsp soy sauce

Salt and pepper to taste

Chili flakes or chopped chili (optional)

1 egg (optional, for serving)

HOW TO COOK?

1. Boil and Grill
Boil the pork until tender, then grill or pan-fry until crispy. Chop finely.

2. SautÃ© and Mix
In a pan, sautÃ© garlic and onion, then add chopped pork. Add soy sauce, calamansi, and chili if using. Stir well.

3. Add Creaminess
Turn off the heat and mix in mayonnaise (this gives it that signature creamy texture). Season to taste.

4. Serve on Sizzling Plate
(Optional) Serve on a hot sizzling plate and crack an egg on top. Mix well and enjoy!

Lumpiang
Shanghai

See complete recipe

chef_hat

Lumpiang Shanghai

INGREDIENTS

500g ground pork

1 medium carrot (grated)

1 small onion (minced)

3 cloves garlic (minced)

1 egg

2 tbsp soy sauce

Salt and pepper to taste

25 pcs lumpia wrapper

Cooking oil (for deep frying)

HOW TO COOK?

1. Mix the Filling
In a bowl, combine ground pork, carrots, onion, garlic, egg, soy sauce, salt, and pepper. Mix thoroughly.

2. Wrap the Lumpia
Place 1 spoonful of filling on a wrapper. Roll tightly and seal the edge with water or egg wash. Repeat for all.

3. Fry to Golden
Heat oil in a deep pan and fry the lumpia in batches until golden brown and crispy.

4. Serve with Sauce
Serve hot with sweet chili sauce or ketchup on the side.

chef_hat

Bicol Express

INGREDIENTS

500g pork belly (sliced into strips)

2 cups coconut milk

1 cup coconut cream

4 cloves garlic (minced)

1 onion (chopped)

1 thumb-sized ginger (sliced)

4-6 pcs green or red chili (siling haba)

1-2 pcs red chili (siling labuyo, optional)

2 tbsp shrimp paste (bagoong alamang)

Salt to taste

HOW TO COOK?

1. SautÃ© the Base
SautÃ© garlic, onion, and ginger until fragrant. Add the pork and cook until lightly browned.

2. Add Coconut Milk
Pour in the coconut milk and let it simmer until pork is tender, about 25â€“30 minutes.

3. Add Bagoong & Chilies
Stir in the shrimp paste and chilies. Simmer for another 10 minutes.

4. Finish with Coconut Cream
Add the coconut cream and cook until thick and creamy. Season with salt if needed.

5. Serve Hot
Serve with steamed rice and brace yourself for the creamy spice!
